description:
Actinomyces provencensis is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Actinomyces. It is a Gram-positive, anaerobic, and non-spore-forming actinobacterium. Actinomyces provencensis was first isolated from a human clinical sample in Provence, France, hence the species name "provencensis."

This bacterium is known to be a part of the normal human oral and gastrointestinal microbiota. It can, however, occasionally cause opportunistic infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Actinomyces provencensis has been associated with various clinical conditions, including abscesses, infections of the head and neck region, and even systemic infections.

Phenotypically, Actinomyces provencensis forms small, white to gray, dry colonies on agar media. It is a fastidious organism, requiring specialized growth conditions and media for successful cultivation in the laboratory. Genetically, Actinomyces provencensis is characterized by a high G+C content in its DNA, a feature common among actinobacteria.

Further research is needed to fully understand the ecology, pathogenicity, and clinical significance of this relatively newly described species within the Actinomyces genus.
